summary: This is an email chain from October 15, 2020, between an FBI forensic examiner and an Assistant U.S. Attorney in the Southern District of New York regarding the status of image and video files extracted from devices seized in the Epstein investigation. The AUSA notes that folders for one device appear empty and lists several other devices for which they are awaiting data.

persons.name: Sunny Drescher
persons.role: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: FBI contractor and forensic examiner who is being asked to check on the status of image and video files from Epstein devices.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: Prosecutor in the SDNY who received Epstein device files, identified that folders for one device are empty, and is inquiring about the status of files from several other devices.

connections.person2: Assistant United States Attorney Southern District of New York
connections.description: Drescher, an FBI forensic examiner, is corresponding with the AUSA regarding the forensic review of devices seized in the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Email inquiry about Epstein device files
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney emails an FBI forensic examiner to inquire about the status of image and video files extracted from devices seized in the Epstein investigation, noting one device folder is empty and listing others pending.
personsInvolved: Assistant United States Attorney Southern District of New York

keyFacts: The document is an email chain dated October 15, 2020, concerning forensic evidence in the Epstein investigation.
An Assistant U.S. Attorney reports that folders for device NYC024342 appear empty, indicating a potential issue with data extraction or storage.
The AUSA lists at least eight other devices (NYC024328, NYC024329, NYC024353, NYC024365, NYC024366, NYC024371, NYC024383) from which image and video files are still awaited.
The correspondence involves an FBI forensic examiner (Sunny Drescher) and a federal prosecutor, showing ongoing investigative work years after Epstein's death.
The document is subject to a protective order, indicating the sensitive nature of the evidence discussed.
